image.title: DW.DE
image.description: News, Analysis and Service from Germany and Europe - in 30 Languages

item.title: Ukrainian army refuses to start withdrawing heavy weapons
item.description: Attacks by pro-Russian rebels have delayed withdrawal of heavy weapons from the front line, Ukrainian army sources say. Both sides in the conflict had previously agreed to pull back the weapons within two weeks.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: German business confidence jumps again
item.description: Managers' confidence in the German economy has risen as exporters take advantage of favorable conditions. It was yet another positive sign for the strength of Europe's largest economy.
item.dc:subject: Business

item.title: Egypt sentences activist to five years in prison
item.description: Prominent Egyptian activist Alaa Abdel Fattah has been sentenced to five years imprisonment for organizing an illegal protest in 2014. The demonstration took place just two days after a law banning protests was passed.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Study: Pollution shortening lives of 660 million Indians
item.description: India's air pollution is cutting the lives of 660 million people by about three years, a new study found. DW speaks to Nicholas Ryan, one of the study's authors, about how severe the country's air problems have become.
item.dc:subject: World

item.title: HSBC profits drop amid tax, CEO controversy
item.description: British bank HSBC has announced a sharp drop in profit after fines and settlements hit its bottom line. The earnings report followed revelations the embattled bank's CEO hid millions of pounds in a secret Swiss account.
item.dc:subject: Business

item.title: Dax reaches another high after Greece deal
item.description: Germany's blue-chip share index, the DAX, reached a new high on Monday following the eurozone's finance ministers' agreement with Greece on its bailout program. London's FTSE also initially traded near its record peak.
item.dc:subject: Business

item.title: Child pornography trial begins against ex-German lawmaker Sebastian Edathy
item.description: The trial of former German politician Sebastian Edathy has begun. Over the past year, child pornography allegations have destroyed the career of the once-rising star in Germany's SPD Party.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Music made in Germany: 5 new albums to watch for
item.description: Want to spice up your playlist? DW has picked a handful (literally) of German artists with new albums out. From Deichkind's electro-pop to Prag's retro chanson, there's something for you here, too.
item.dc:subject: Culture

item.title: Greece puts final touches on reform proposal for troika
item.description: Athens has been dotting the i's and crossing the t's on a new list of reform measures. If European lenders approve its proposal, Athens will be given a loan extension, narrowly avoiding insolvency.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Birdman wins Best Picture at 87th Oscars
item.description: Black comedy-drama Birdman has scooped the big prize of the night at this year's Oscars. The film won Best Picture as well as Best Director for Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Opinion: Open wounds in Ukraine
item.description: One year on, the crimes that took place on the Maidan are still unpunished. Last February, Ukrainians won against a corrupt regime but their desire for a better life remains unfulfilled, says DW's Bernd Johann.
item.dc:subject: World

item.title: Al-Shabab threatens Western shopping centers
item.description: In a new video, Somalia-based terror group al-Shabab has threatened Western shopping centers including one of the largest malls in the the US. Homeland Security Secretary Jeh Johnson is taking the threat "seriously."
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Nearly 500 miners rescued from South African gold mine
item.description: All 486 miners trapped after a fire broke out in a South African gold mine over the weekend have been rescued. Some of the miners were trapped at a depth of nearly 3.5 kilometers.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: US commanders convene in Kuwait to assess anti-IS campaign
item.description: Top US commanders are due to meet in Kuwait on Monday to assess the multinational campaign against "Islamic State" jihadists in Syria and Iraq. New US Defense Secretary Ashton Carter will convene the meeting.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Marco Reus: "I want to win the Bundesliga with Dortmund"
item.description: The 25-year-old put pen-to-paper on a long-term extension at Dortmund in February, ending months of speculation over whether he would leave the club this summer.
item.dc:subject: Sports

item.title: Lampedusa suffers under weight of Europe's refugee crisis
item.description: Since the end of Mare Nostrum and the flare-up of the war in Libya, more than 1,000 people have landed on Lampedusa. The island's residents fear the worst is yet to come. Karl Hoffmann reports from there.
item.dc:subject: World

item.title: Free-scoring Dost strikes again as Wolfsburg beat Hertha
item.description: Bas Dost's incredible scoring streak continued following his four goals at Leverkusen last weekend. The Wolves moved to within eight points of Bayern at the top while Hertha Berlin face a tough battle to escape the drop.
item.dc:subject: Sports

item.title: Islam expert on why German youth are 'ready to kill'
item.description: Why are young Germans joining the ranks of Islamists and waging jihad? Islamic studies expert Lamya Kaddor explains why youth, Muslim or not, are particularly susceptible to the indoctrination of Salafist recruiters.
item.dc:subject: Germany

item.title: Hrgota snatches late point for Gladbach at Hamburg
item.description: A late equalizer from Branimir Hrgota dampened the mood at the Volkspark, which had been sensing a win. Gladbach stayed in control of their Champions League destiny, but it could be two points lost in the race for 2nd.
item.dc:subject: Sports

item.title: Kharkiv bombing overshadows Maidan anniversary march in Ukraine
item.description: EU President Donald Tusk and German President Joachim Gauck have marked the Maidan anniversary in Ukraine's capital, Kyiv. The event was overshadowed by a bombing in Kharkiv, which left two people dead.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Deadly explosion rips through eastern Ukraine city of Kharkiv
item.description: An explosive device that went off in a crowd of marchers celebrating Ukraine's 2014 revolution has caused over a dozen casualties. The country's Interior Ministry condemned the "terrorist act" far from the frontline.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Greece races to finalize reform measures ahead of deadline
item.description: Greece is rushing to finalize a raft of reform measures that would spare it from bankruptcy and secure a four-month extension of its bailout program. Athens says the proposals will bring the economy "out of sedation."
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Israeli ambassador to Germany calls on Europe's Jews to emigrate
item.description: The Israeli ambassador in Berlin has urged Jews to leave Europe and move to Israel. European anti-Semitism has made Jewish communities feel threatened, according to the diplomat.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: German government says no tanks for Lithuania: report
item.description: The German government has rejected a request from Lithuania for Boxer tanks, according to a newspaper report. The decision has been criticized by both sides of the German governing coalition.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Opinion: Manifesto for a modern Islam
item.description: Muslim intellectuals have called for their fellow believers to indentify societal failures and develop an Islam for the 21st century. Loay Mudhoon believes that Europe should unreservedly support this effort.
item.dc:subject: World

item.title: Matteo Renzi stands firm at Italy's helm
item.description: A year into his term, Matteo Renzi is firmly ensconced as Italy's prime minister with little to fear from the opposition. His supposed allies, however, could eventually pose a problem. Megan Williams reports from Rome.
item.dc:subject: World

item.title: Hidden Cezanne sketches found, offer glimpse of 'artistic process'
item.description: Two sketches by French artist Paul Cezanne have been discovered hidden on the reverse side of two watercolors sent for conservatory work. Although unfinished drafts, they offer "a window into Cezanne's artistic process."
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Hollande appeals to own party after forcing through economic reforms
item.description: French President Francois Hollande has called for "responsibility" and "lucidity" from his Socialist lawmakers, days after his government was forced to ram an economic reforms package through parliament without a vote.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Opinion: Love your language!
item.description: Some Germans lament, "Our language has never been in worse shape." And some even worry an English invasion will make their language obsolete. What better time to worry than on International Mother Language Day.
item.dc:subject: World

item.title: Goma: The DRC's phoenix city that has risen from the ashes
item.description: Goma airport, in the Democratic Republic of Congo, is being rebuilt after being half-buried by a volcano. Frank-Walter Steinmeier has become the first German foreign minister to visit. DW's Claus Stäcker reports.
item.dc:subject: World

item.title: Moody's downgrades Russian credit rating, following S&P
item.description: Ratings agency Moody's now regards Russian sovereign debt as non-investment grade - a term commonly known as "junk" status. Moscow said the reduction from Baa3 to Ba1 was based on "factors of a political character."
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Karsten Mühlenfeld takes over 'new' Berlin BER airport
item.description: Rolls-Royce is better known for jet engines than airport administration, yet a former executive, Karsten Mühlenfeld, is to take charge of the new Berlin BER hub. Terminally delayed, can he get it open?
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: African graduates flood Germany's job market
item.description: Over the last couple of years the number of students from sub-Saharan Africa, who come to study and work in Germany, has increased. But getting a job can be difficult depending on the field of study one is taking.
item.dc:subject: World

item.title: Pass the potato chips - why stoners get the munchies
item.description: Thanks to a team of Yale researchers, we now know exactly why smoking marijuana stimulates the urge to dive into a bag of chips.
item.dc:subject: Sci-Tech

item.title: In Berlin, remembering a 'martyr'
item.description: Following the assassination of 21 of their brethrens by extremists in Libya, Germany’s Coptic community gathered in Berlin to commemorate the dead. DW’s Naomi Conrad met a mourner whose cousin was among those murdered.
item.dc:subject: Germany

item.title: Shooting in Philippines leaves German dead
item.description: At argument at a fast food restaurant between two locals and two foreigners erupted into a deadly shooting. A German man, presumed to have been a bystander, was killed.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: WHO approves 15-minute Ebola test
item.description: The World Health Organization (WHO) has approved the first rapid test for Ebola. Corgenix's test is less accurate than the standard test but is easy to perform giving results within 15 minutes.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Drug-resistant malaria found near Indian border
item.description: A drug-resistant strain of malaria from Southeast Asia can be found within 25 kilometers of the Indian border, potentially posing a serious threat to the global control and eradication of the disease, a new study found.
item.dc:subject: World

item.title: Apple e-car ready in 2020: report
item.description: Apple could be ready to produce an electric car within five years, a news report claimed on Thursday. But the technology giant is also facing a lawsuit for allegedly poaching employees.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Star conductor Eschenbach shares secrets to happiness
item.description: In war-struck Germany, it was music that gave the child Christoph Eschenbach a fresh start in life. Turning 75 on February 20, the world-renowned conductor says music keeps him from aging.
item.dc:subject: Culture

item.title: Drones to scan Brazil's Amazon forest
item.description: The mysteries of the Amazon and its history still lie far below the cover of the forest's leaves. But now scientists are using drones to try to uncover the secrets of the ancient civilizations that once called it home.
item.dc:subject: Environment

item.title: Gladbach cling on in Spain, Wolfsburg beat Sporting
item.description: Both of Germany's representatives will feel their Europa League fates are in their own hands after Gladbach lost narrowly away and Wolfsburg opened a two-goal cushion at home, in the first legs of their last 32 ties.
item.dc:subject: Sports

item.title: Poland's pre-war code crackers
item.description: The Oscar-nominated film The Imitation Game is based on the life of British mathematical genius Alan Turing, whose team broke the Nazi Enigma code. But their triumph was built on the groundwork of Polish mathematicians.
item.dc:subject: Sci-Tech

item.title: German job market keeps on booming
item.description: Employment figures in Germany have increased once again, defying the ongoing euro crisis. More than 43 million people had work in the country in the last quarter of 2014 - the highest number since reunification.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Poverty in Germany at its highest since reunification
item.description: Poverty in Germany is at it's highest since German reunification in 1990, according to a new study. Some 12.5 million Germans are now classified as poor.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Dogs recognize human facial expressions
item.description: Angry or happy? Dogs can tell the difference by looking at people's faces. But, do they understand what the expressions mean? Dog owners believe this to be the case, but there is no scientific proof.
item.dc:subject: Sci-Tech

item.title: German film tells Anne Frank's story through her father's eyes
item.description: It's been nearly 70 years since Anne Frank was killed in a Nazi concentration camp. The director of a new German-made docudrama on her life, broadcast this week, tells DW what makes his film so unique.
item.dc:subject: Culture

item.title: German court limits performances of Brecht play
item.description: Berthold Brecht's heirs and notorious theater director Frank Castorf have reached an agreement over a controversial production of Bertolt Brecht's "Baal." The production will only be shown two more times.
item.dc:subject: Culture

item.title: The global climate needs greener transport
item.description: Wind and solar energy have made power generation greener worldwide, but CO2 emissions continue to rise as more and more cars take to the roads. Experts are working hard on new solutions.
item.dc:subject: Environment

item.title: The hitchhiking robot's guide to Germany
item.description: A hitchhiking Canadian robot is endearing itself to Germans on a tour that includes a stop at the Brandenburg Gate in Berlin. The robot relies on the kindness of strangers (and their cars) to get around.
item.dc:subject: Sci-Tech

item.title: New York Fashion Week with a male model from Germany
item.description: Walking the catwalk at New York Fashion Week is any model's dream. But the job can be a lot less glamorous than it might seem. DW spent a day with an aspiring male model.
item.dc:subject: Culture

item.title: Scuba divers discover hoard of ancient gold in Israel
item.description: As children, we've probably all fantasized about uncovering an ancient buried treasure? Scuba divers have done just that. They found a priceless trove of gold coins - the largest ever discovered in Israel.
item.dc:subject: Culture

item.title: Ozone layer under threat, again?
item.description: Researchers are warning about the damage to the ozone layer by "very short-lived substances" or VSLS gases. Although the compounds occur naturally, our own production is rising.
item.dc:subject: Sci-Tech

item.title: UK politicians unite to shut down coal
item.description: A new agreement between three major UK political parties aims to cut carbon emissions by phasing out coal. But environmentalists are disappointed the agreement fails to mention a time frame.
item.dc:subject: Environment

item.title: IAEA: 'Significant progress' at Fukushima
item.description: For a third time, IAEA experts have examined the progress Japan has made in cleaning up the crippled Fukushima nuclear plant. They praised reduced radiation levels and called for resolving water contamination problems.
item.dc:subject: World

item.title: 'We have to create the Digital Single Market'
item.description: Europe has achieved a single market in the offline world. But what about the bloc's digital realm? DW speaks to Andrus Ansip, the European Commission's new vice-president for the Digital Single Market.
item.dc:subject: Sci-Tech

item.title: Berlin through the Instagram lens
item.description: February in Berlin is grey, icy and damp. But (for that very reason?), it's still a favorite muse on Instagram. For an edgy take on the city or to get involved in the Berlin Instagram scene, here's what to watch for.
item.dc:subject: Culture

item.title: Controversy of killing for conservation
item.description: Should scientists kill newly discovered yet endangered species in order to study them? Some prefer to rely on conservation-friendly photographic material, but the method is controversial.
item.dc:subject: Environment

item.title: Ancient traditions protect the environment in East Timor
item.description: Indepedent since 2002, East Timor is one of the world's newest nations. But when it comes to protecting the environment, it has a unique and ancient tradition to draw upon - the practice of tara bandu.
item.dc:subject: Environment

item.title: Norway to become Germany's energy reservoir
item.description: A submarine power cable is set to link Norwegian hydroelectric plants and German wind farms starting in 2020. A powerhouse for Europe, Norwegian hydropower plays an important role in the renewable energy revolution.
item.dc:subject: Environment

item.title: World's oceans choking on plastic waste
item.description: Plastic is ubiquitous today, found in many consumer items. But once these products are thrown away, they often end up in the world's oceans, where they make their way through the ecosystem and - perhaps - back to us.
item.dc:subject: Environment
